[[File:Goyaale.jpg|thumb|[[Apache]] [[Tribal chief|chief]] [[Geronimo]] (1829-1909), the namesake of the [[code name]] used in the [[Death of Osama bin Laden|Bin Laden raid]].]] The '''code name Geronimo controversy''' came about after media reports that the U.S. operation to [[Death of Osama bin Laden|kill Osama bin Laden]] used the [[code name]] "Geronimo" to refer to either the overall operation, to fugitive bin Laden himself or to the act of killing or capturing bin Laden.
Press reports claimed that "Geronimo" was used in the raid to refer to bin Laden himself,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/05/02/eveningnews/main20059015.shtml?tag=pop|title=To the bottom of the sea: Bin Laden's last day|publisher=CBS Evening News|date=2 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/03/world/asia/03intel.html?_r=2 |title=Behind the Hunt for Bin Laden|publisher=New York Times | date = 2 May 2011 | accessdate = 9 May 2011 }}</ref> but this was later contradicted by official sources.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/US/05/05/bin.laden.geronimo/index.html|title=Native Americans object to linking Geronimo to bin Laden|publisher=CNN}}</ref> The official mission [[code name]] was ''Operation Neptune Spear''<ref name="abcnewskillmission">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2011/05/us-official-this-was-a-kill-mission.html|title=US Official: "This Was a Kill Mission"|author=Jake Tapper|publisher=ABC News}}</ref><ref>[https://twitter.com/GMA/statuses/65551207896317952 @GMA Twitter, 5/3]</ref> (a reference to the [[trident]] in the [[SEAL]] [[Special Warfare insignia|insignia]]), with ''Jackpot'' as the code name for bin Laden as an individual and ''Geronimo'' as the code word for bin Laden's capture or death.<ref>{{cite news|title='For God and Country Geronimo, Geronimo, Geromimo'|date=May 3, 2011|url=http://blogs.cbn.com/beltwaybuzz/archive/2011/05/03/for-god-and-country-geronimo-geronimo-geromimo.aspx|work=CBN News|publisher=Christian Broadcasting Network|accessdate=May 4, 2011}}</ref> In the book ''[[No Easy Day]]'', former SEAL Matt Bissonnette, who participated in the mission, states that "Geronimo" was the code name for bin Laden.<ref>Owen, Mark, and Kevin Maurer, ''[[No Easy Day]]'' (2012), Chapter 10, [[Dutton Penguin]]</ref>
The historical [[Geronimo]] was a leader of the [[Chiricahua|Chiricahua Apache]] who defied the U.S. government and eluded capture.
''[[Channel 4 News]]'' said "According to some analysis today, the U.S. military chose the code name because bin Laden, like Geronimo, had evaded capture for years. If they were trying to avoid mythmaking, it seems they chose the wrong code name."<ref>"[http://www.channel4.com/news/why-was-the-bin-laden-operation-called-geronimo Target bin Laden: why was he code named 'Geronimo'?]." [[Channel 4 News]]. May 3, 2011. Retrieved on May 3, 2011.</ref> Once bin Laden was killed, one of the commanders reported "Geronimo E-KIA", meaning that the mission had ended with the "Enemy [[Killed In Action]]".<ref>"[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/05/02/eveningnews/main20059015.shtml?tag=pop To the bottom of the sea: Bin Laden's last day]." ''[[CBS News]]''. May 2, 2011. Retrieved on May 4, 2011.</ref>
Many Native Americans objected to the use of the name ''Geronimo''. "It's how deeply embedded the 'Indian as enemy' is in the collective mind of America," said [[Suzan Shown Harjo]], president of the Washington, D.C.-based Morning Star Institute, a Native American advocacy group.<ref>{{cite news|last=King|first=Ledyard|title=Indian leaders cry foul over bin Laden 'Geronimo' nickname|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2011-05-05-bin-laden-american-indians-geronimo_n.htm|accessdate=20 May 2011|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=May 6, 2011}}</ref> "There is little doubt [the] use of a leader like Geronimo to refer to bin Laden is ill-advised," wrote [[Keith Harper (lawyer)|Keith Harper]], an attorney and member of the [[Cherokee Nation]], in an email with a reporter for ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tucker, Neely|title=American Indians object to 'Geronimo' as code for bin Laden raid|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/american-indians-object-to-geronimo-as-code-name-for-bin-laden-raid/2011/05/03/AF2FZIjF_story.html|date=May 3, 2011|work=The Washington Post |accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref>
{{Quote box | quote = "Geronimo is a hero. He’s a national patriot for our peoples. And in that, it is indeed an egregious slander for [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous peoples]] everywhere and to all Americans, I believe, to equate Osama bin Laden with Geronimo. The reality is, is that the military is full of native [[nomenclature]]. You’ve got [[Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk|Black Hawk helicopters]], [[Boeing AH-64 Apache|Apache Longbow helicopters]]. You’ve got [[Tomahawk (missile)|Tomahawk missiles]] [...] The U.S. military still has individuals dressed—the [[7th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|Seventh Cavalry]], that went in<!--NOT a mistake--> in [[2003 invasion of Iraq|Shock and Awe]], is the same cavalry that massacred indigenous people, the [[Lakota people]], at [[Wounded Knee Massacre|Wounded Knee]] in 1890. You know, that is the reality of military nomenclature and how the military basically uses native people and native imagery to continue its global war and its global empire practices." | source = — [[Winona LaDuke]], activist and author of ''The Militarization of Indian Country'', on ''[[Democracy Now!]]''<ref>[http://www.democracynow.org/2011/5/6/native_american_activist_winona_laduke_on Native American Activist Winona LaDuke on Use of "Geronimo" as Code for Osama bin Laden: "The Continuation of the Wars Against Indigenous People"] — video report by ''[[Democracy Now!]]'', May 6, 2011</ref> | width = 35% | align = right }}
The leaders of several Native American Indian tribes urged President Obama to retroactively rename the military code name "Geronimo" used by the SEALS during the killing of bin Laden.<ref name="Tribes">{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/blog/inside-politics/2011/may/4/indian-tribes-strike-geronimo-bin-laden-operation-/|title=Indian tribes: Strike Geronimo from bin Laden operation name|author=Stephen Dinan|work=The Washington Times |date=May 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/04/us-binladen-geronimo-idUSTRE74378U20110504?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews|title=Bin Laden, Geronimo link angers Native Americans|date=May 4, 2011|author=Michelle Nichols|agency=Reuters }}</ref><ref name="Montoya">{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/us_bin_laden_geronimo|title=AP NewsBreak: Geronimo's tribe seeks apology|author=Susan Montoya Bryan|agency=Associated Press|date=May 4, 2011}}</ref> Fort Sill Apache Tribal Chairman Jeff Houser sent a letter to President Obama, decrying the linking of "the legendary Apache warrior" to a "mass murder and cowardly terrorist...Unlike the coward Osama bin Laden, Geronimo faced his enemy in numerous battles and engagements. He is perhaps one of the greatest symbols of Native American resistance in the history of the United States."<ref name="Montoya"/> Questions to the White House about the code name were referred to the Defense Department, which stated no disrespect was meant and that code names are generally chosen at random. Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly told ''[[The Washington Times]]'' that "Even though the operation to capture or kill bin Laden is over...the name should be changed so that children don't encounter it in the history books."<ref name="Tribes"/>
The [[Onondaga people|Onondaga]] Council of Chiefs said that the use of code name Geronimo perpetuates negative stereotypes about Indians.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Onondagas-Rip-Osamas-Geronimo-Code-Name-121246039.html|title=Onondagas Rip Osama's "Geronimo" Code Name|date=4 May 2011}}</ref> [[Nez Perce tribe|Nez Perce]] member Loretta Tuell, staff director and chief counsel for the [[Senate Indian Affairs Committee]], said "These inappropriate uses of Native American icons and cultures are prevalent throughout our society, and the impacts to Native and non-Native children are devastating".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2011/05/onondaga_nation_leaders_blast.html|title=Onondaga Nation leaders blast 'Geronimo' codename for Bin Laden|date=4 May 2011}}</ref> Jeff Houser, chairman of Geronimo's [[Fort Sill Apache Tribe]], wrote a letter to President Obama saying "We are quite certain that the use of the name Geronimo as a code for Osama bin Laden was based on misunderstood and misconceived historical perspectives of Geronimo and his armed struggle against the United States and Mexican governments".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/world/breakingnews/apnewsbreak-fort-sill-apache-leader-seeks-apology-from-obama-over-use-of-geronimo-code-name-121275979.html|title=Senate panel to discuss Geronimo code name, Native American concerns about racial stereotypes|date=5 May 2011}}</ref>
Geronimo's great-grandson, [[Vietnam War]] veteran Harlyn Geronimo, issued a statement requesting explanations and apologies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/05/10/136173831/code-name-geronimo-sparks-anger|date=10 May 2011|title=Code Name 'Geronimo' Sparks Anger}}</ref>
On 8 May 2011, President Obama was interviewed by ''[[60 Minutes]]'' saying "There was a point before folks had left, before we had gotten everybody back on the helicopter and were flying back to base, where they said Geronimo has been killed, and Geronimo was the code name for bin Laden."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/ict_sbc/geronimo-was-the-code-name-for-bin-laden/|title=Geronimo was the Code Name for bin Laden|author=Steven Newcomb |date=11 May 2011}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Indigenous peoples of North America|Politics}} * [[Stereotypes of Native Americans]] * [[Geronimo (exclamation)]]

{{unreferenced|date=May 2016}} [[File:CAFx_logo_2016.png|right|frameless]] '''Copenhagen Architecture Festival''' (CAFx) was founded in 2014 in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] at the initiative of Josephine Michau, Peter Møller Rasmussen and Mads Farsø. The title of the festival's first year (2014) was Copenhagen Architecture Festival x Film with a strong focus on the film medium. In 2015, the festival expanded to exhibitions, master classes and seminars as well to a further festival edition in [[Aarhus]]: Aarhus Architecture Festival (AAFx). The number of visitors doubled from 4.000 visitors in 2014 to 8.000 visitors in 2015.
Since then, the festival has grown in both scope and ambition. In 2016, the program covered more than 150 events, providing a wide range of approaches to architecture in three cities, as now the festival also runs in [[Aalborg]]: Aalborg Architecture Festival (ALAFx). Furthermore, the festival organized its first Summer School on Film and Architecture in August 2016 in Aarhus, inviting 6 architects and artists to run 3 masterclasses.
In 2017, all three festival editions CAFx, AAFx and ALAFx took place simultaneously under the headline "Architecture As Identity", which had a span of over 150 events. As well as last year, CAFx is organizing a Summer School on Film and Landscape, taking place in August 2017 on the Danish west coast of [[Lemvig]].
The goal of the festival is to extend the idea of what architecture can be and how it seeps everywhere in human lives. All of the cities have a strong architectural identity and local ambassadors co-curating and conducting the program.
The festival is led by festival director Josephine Michau and strategic director Mads Farsø. The main supporters of the Festival are Realdania, Dreyers Fond, Københavns Kommune, Det Danske Filminstitut and Statens Kunstfond.
==External links== * [http://cafx.dk/ Copenhagen Architecture Festival] * [http://cafx.dk/ Aarhus Architecture Festival] * [http://cafx.dk/ Aalborg Architecture Festival]

'''Daegu International Opera Festival(DIOF)''' is a [[festival]] that is held in [[Daegu]], [[South Korea]]. The festival takes place in mid October. However, the 16th DIOF commenced in September. Alongside grand opera performances, there are a host of programs in DIOF such as back stage tour, square opera, Opera Odessey(free lectures regarding opera), pre-concert, lucky seats etc.<ref>{{official website|http://www.diof.org/}} {{ko icon}} {{en icon}}</ref>
==History== Daegu International Opera Festival(DIOF) is the representative music festival in South Korea and is the largest International Opera Festival in Asia. The festival has accomplished an enormous growth since its commencement. DIOF continuously endeavors to culturally enlighten people. Moreover, it functions as an Asian cultural hub by bringing various high quality foreign productions. DIOF may be the only chance to enjoy a lot of rare combinations of renowned artists.

{{Redirect2|Deepavali|Dipawali|other uses|Deepavali (disambiguation)}} {{Use Indian English|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Diwali |type = Hindu |nickname = Deepavali |image = The Rangoli of Lights.jpg |caption = [[Rangoli]] decorations, made using coloured powder or sand, are popular during Diwali. |observedby = [[Hindu]]s, [[Sikhs]], [[Jainism|Jains]] and [[Newar Buddhism|Newar Buddhists]]Charles M Townsend, TheOxford Handbook of Sikh Studies, Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|978-0199699308}}, p. 440 |litcolor = |longtype = Cultural, seasonal, religious |begins = [[Dhanteras]] |ends = [[Bhai Dooj]] |date = Varies per [[Hindu calendar]] |celebrations = [[Diya (light)|Diya]] and lighting, home decoration, shopping, fireworks, [[Puja (Hinduism)|puja]] (worship ceremonies), gifts, performing religious rituals, feast and sweets |date2018 = 6 November (Tuesday) in [[Tamil Nadu]]{{cite web|url=https://www.india.gov.in/calendar?date=2018-11|title=Holiday calendar |publisher=National Portal of India |accessdate=21 June 2018}}
[[Southeast Asia]]: [[Singapore]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mom.gov.sg/employment-practices/public-holidays |title=Public holidays |publisher=Ministry of Manpower, Singapore |accessdate=21 June 2018}} [[Malaysia]]site web|url=https://publicholidays.com.my/deepavali/ 7 November (Wednesday) in [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[Telangana]], [[Karnataka]], [[Kerala]], and [[North India]] |relatedto = [[Kali Puja]], [[Galungan]], [[Diwali (Jainism)]], [[Bandi Chhor Divas]], [[Tihar (festival)|Tihar]], [[Swanti (festival)|Swanti]] }} '''Diwali''', '''Deepavali''' or '''Dipavali''' is the [[Hindu]] festival of lights, which is celebrated every autumn in the northern hemisphere (spring in southern hemisphere).The New Oxford Dictionary of English (1998) {{ISBN|0-19-861263-X}}. p. 540 "'''Diwali''' /dɪwɑːli/ (also '''Divali''') '''noun''' a Hindu festival with lights...".[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/166786/Diwali Diwali] ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' (2009) One of the most popular festivals of [[Hinduism]], Diwali symbolises the spiritual "victory of light over darkness, good over evil and knowledge over ignorance." Light is a metaphor for knowledge and consciousness.{{cite book|author1=Vasudha Narayanan|author2=Deborah Heiligman|title=Celebrate Diwali|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rdTJJEQsDHoC&pg=PA31|year=2008|publisher=National Geographic Society|isbn=978-1-4263-0291-6|page=31}}, '''Quote:''' "All the stories associated with Deepavali, however, speak of the joy connected with the victory of light over darkness, knowledge over ignorance, and good over evil".Jean Mead, How and why Do Hindus Celebrate Divali?, {{ISBN|978-0-237-534-127}} During the celebration, temples, homes, shops and office buildings are brightly illuminated.Frank Salamone (2004), Encyclopedia of Religious Rites, Rituals and Festivals, {{ISBN|978-0415880916}}, Routledge, pp. 112–13, 174, 252 The preparations, and rituals, for the festival typically last five days, with the climax occurring on the third day coinciding with the darkest night of the [[Hindu calendar|Hindu lunisolar]] month [[Kartika (month)|Kartika]]. In the [[Gregorian calendar]], the festival generally falls between mid-October and mid-November. In the lead-up to Diwali, celebrants will prepare by cleaning, renovating, and decorating their homes and workplaces.{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/?id=6A9EZRQIT9kC&pg=PA109 |title = Meri Khoj Ek Bharat Ki|author=Pramodkumar|quote=It is extremely important to keep the house spotlessly clean and pure on Diwali. The Goddess Lakshmi likes cleanliness, and she will visit the cleanest house first. Lamps are lit in the evening to welcome the goddess. They are believed to light up her path.|accessdate = 26 October 2011|isbn = 978-1-4357-1240-9|date = March 2008}} During the climax, revellers adorn themselves in their finest clothes, illuminate the interior and exterior of their homes with ''[[Diya (lamp)|diyas]]'' (oil lamps or candles), offer ''puja'' (worship) to [[Lakshmi]], the goddess of prosperity and wealth,{{refn|group=note|Hindus of eastern and northeastern states of India associate the festival with the goddess [[Durga]], or her fierce avatar [[Kali]] ([[Shaktism]]).{{sfn|Laura Amazzone|2012|}} According to McDermott, this region too celebrated Lakshmi puja historically, and the Kali puja tradition started in the colonial era, particularly after the 1920s.{{sfn|McDermott|2011|pp=183–88}}}} light fireworks, and partake in family feasts, where ''mithai'' ([[South Asian sweets|sweets]]) and gifts are shared. Diwali is also a major cultural event for the Hindu and Jain diaspora from the Indian subcontinent.[https://www.webcitation.org/6LYPWvqVY?url=http://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2010/08/23/india-journal-tis-the-season-to-be-shopping/ India Journal: ‘Tis the Season to be Shopping] Devita Saraf, The Wall Street Journal (August 2010){{sfn|Henry Johnson|2007|pp=71–73}}{{sfn|Kelly|1988|pp=40–55}} The five-day festival originated in the [[Indian subcontinent]] and is mentioned in early [[Sanskrit]] texts. The names of the festive days of Diwali, as well as the rituals, vary by region. Diwali is usually celebrated eighteen days after the [[Navrati|Dussehra]] (Dasara, Dasain) festival with [[Dhanteras]], or the regional equivalent, marking the first day of the festival when celebrants prepare by cleaning their homes and making decorations on the floor, such as ''[[rangoli]]''.Karen Bellenir (1997), Religious Holidays and Calendars: An Encyclopedic Handbook, 2nd Edition, {{ISBN|978-0780802582}}, Omnigraphics The second day is ''Choti Diwali'', or equivalent in north India, while for Hindus in the south of India it is Diwali proper. Western, central, eastern and northern Indian communities observe Diwali on the third day and the darkest night of the traditional month. In some parts of India, the day after Diwali is marked with the ''Govardhan Puja'' and ''Diwali Padva'', which is dedicated to the relationship between wife and husband. Some Hindu communities mark the last day as [[Bhai Dooj]], which is dedicated to the bond between sister and brother,{{cite book|author1=Rajat Gupta|author2=Nishant Singh|author3=Ishita Kirar|title=Hospitality & Tourism Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DatDDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA84|publisher=Vikas |isbn=978-93-259-8244-4|page=84}} while other Hindu and Sikh craftsmen communities mark this day as ''[[Vishwakarma Puja]]'' and observe it by performing maintenance in their work spaces and offering prayers.{{cite book|author1=Kristen Haar|author2=Sewa Singh Kalsi|title=Sikhism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YOI1nB_zTyAC |year=2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-0647-2|pages=98–99}}{{cite book|author=Shobhna Gupta|title=Festivals of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g4TtrdejbTEC&pg=PA84 |year=2002|publisher=Har-Anand |isbn=978-81-241-0869-7|page=84}} Some other faiths in India also celebrate their respective festivals alongside Diwali. The [[Jainism|Jains]] observe their own Diwali, which marks the final liberation of [[Mahavira]],{{Cite book|year=2006|title=Fairs and Festivals of India|first=S.P.|last=Sharma|first2= Seema|last2= Gupta|publisher= Pustak Mahal|isbn=978-81-223-0951-5|page=79|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wPPr9HdmnHcC&pg=PA79&dq=diwali+mahavira+527}}{{cite journal|title=Mahavira and His Teachings|first=A.N.|last=Upadhye|editor-first=Richard J.|editor-last=Cohen|journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society|volume=102|date=Jan–Mar 1982|pages=231–32|doi=10.2307/601199|jstor=601199|issue=1}} the [[Sikhism|Sikh]]s celebrate [[Bandi Chhor Divas]] to mark the release of Guru [[Hargobind]] from a [[Mughal Empire]] prison,{{cite book|author=Geoff Teece|title= Sikhism|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kJO1WIABhPQC&pg=PA23| year=2005|isbn=978-1-58340-469-0 |page=23}} while [[Newar Buddhism|Newar Buddhists]], unlike other Buddhists, celebrate Diwali by worshiping Lakshmi.{{cite book|author=Prem Saran|title=Yoga, Bhoga and Ardhanariswara: Individuality, Wellbeing and Gender in Tantra|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5-DfCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA175 |year=2012|publisher =Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-51648-1|page=175}} The festival of Diwali is an official holiday in [[Fiji]],[http://www.fiji.gov.fj/Events/2016-FIJI-PUBLIC-HOLIDAYS.aspx Public Holidays], Government of Fiji [[Guyana]],[https://publicholidays.gy/ Public Holidays], Guyana [[India]], [[Malaysia]] (except Sarawak),[http://www.hrdf.com.my/wps/portal/PSMB/MainEN/Resources/Public-Holiday Public Holidays], Government of Malaysia [[Mauritius]],
